name: NPR
text:
The Trump administration has rejected Beijing's maritime claims over large swaths of the economically important South China Sea, wading into a conflict that has pitted China against several Southeast Asian countries with competing claims.
https://t.co/ZeS4O0Tcfb

name: NPR
text:
More than 180 colleges are supporting a legal challenge to stop the Trump administration from stripping international students of their visas.

The schools argue the move jeopardizes the students' health â€” and gives an advantage to foreign nations.
https://t.co/btSQ0GoBYt

name: NPR
text:
Germicidal UV technology has remained largely outside policy-setting conversations about the coronavirus.

But amid concern that the virus can be spread through the air, some restaurants and transit systems are putting the tech to use. 
https://t.co/MAbxYPXNdF

name: NPR
text:
RT @Haekoko: My @NPR piece explores "K-pop" beyond idol music, which dominates Korea's musical representation in & outside the country. Also, why put "K-anything" in a musical genre? Key points from article in thread below:
https://t.co/Nt6EULjwko

name: NPR
text:
A former secretary to deceased Seoul Mayor Park Won-soon detailed 4 years of alleged sexual harassment by him, saying she "suffered and hurt alone during the long hours of silence." Park's funeral was held Monday.
https://t.co/YbcmVj592b

name: NPR
text:
For critics, buildings named after Spanish conquistador Juan de OÃ±ate, a despot who inflicted misery on Native Americans, represent a festering wound.

But some Hispanic New Mexicans are just as adamant that their history be told, not erased.
https://t.co/iys8s1K0wn

name: NPR
text:
With residents on lockdown at a U.K. nursing home, an activities manager found an inspiring project to keep their spirits up â€” recreating iconic album covers with the residents cast as rock stars. 
https://t.co/XQt6YrhHNW

name: NPR
text:
An estimated 1.9 billion people tuned in to watch Live Aid 35 years ago today.  

Bob Geldof, the mastermind behind the unprecedented, star-studded benefit concert, reflects on the milestone and a new documentary.  https://t.co/m6JqCjmjuE

name: NPR
text:
Oregon Gov. Kate Brown announced that indoor social get-togethers of more than 10 people will be prohibited. In West Virginia, Gov. Jim Justice reduced the social gathering limit from 100 to 25.
https://t.co/nm0YpS5Tei

name: NPR
text:
The coronavirus pandemic could push up to 132 million people into hunger by the end of 2020, according to a new report from the United Nations.
https://t.co/SPzhw1bi7h

name: NPR
text:
Fourth-generation funeral director Patrick Kearns says he hasn't experienced anything with the intensity of the COVID-19 pandemic.  

"You don't see it coming. It knocks you over, you get tossed and you're trying to figure out which way is up."
https://t.co/yKA4MeGxiV

name: NPR
text:
New York will require travelers coming from certain states with rising virus cases to show proof that they've completed a form with their contact information and travel plans before they can leave the airport.
https://t.co/kO8o5nxsvi

name: NPR
text:
A Honduran woman fleeing violence in Mexico gave birth after crossing into the U.S. illegally with her family. Two days later, Border Patrol made her choose: Leave her newborn in the U.S. or to go back to Mexico together.
https://t.co/nlgB7JOn4J

text: The authors of the paper, "Ten simple rules for building an anti-racist lab," tell @KQEDScience the list is a starting point and not meant to be comprehensive. https://t.co/prOeXPQ1Fm

name: NPR
text:
Dr. David J. De La Zerda, the director of an ICU in Miami, says many of his patients are in their 20s, 30s and 40s with no medical history. "They get sicker than the previous [wave]," he says.
https://t.co/XD68OUGnOj

name: NPR
text:
Australia is seeing a new surge in coronavirus cases.

A health official for Victoria state, where Melbourne is located, announced 270 new cases on Tuesday and warned of hundreds of hospitalizations in the coming weeks.
https://t.co/qqJpgp2U5B

name: NPR
text:
The Justice Department has put to death 47-year-old Daniel Lee â€” marking the first federal execution since 2003.

The execution came after a chaotic series of court rulings overnight, including an early morning decision by the Supreme Court.
https://t.co/0n8uidqDrW

name: NPR
text:
After weeks of negotiations between the French government and unions, health care workers will get about $208 a month more in their paychecks.

This year's Bastille Day celebrations are also being used to thank those on the front lines of the pandemic.
https://t.co/qDI9cDM0XM

name: NPR
text:
The ACLU is urging Attorney General William Barr to name a special prosecutor to investigate possible violations of protesters' rights, after federal officers deployed tear gas and rubber bullets to clear demonstrators near the White House last month.
https://t.co/aPrpaisoBN

name: NPR
text:
In the age of COVID-19, most people practice social-distancing guidelines when they go into stores and restaurants.

But then there are the nightmare customers who refuse to comply â€” and might yell, get violent or need to be escorted off the premises.
https://t.co/BBMBk65iyu

text:
Federal prosecutors have charged a former nursing assistant at a medical center for veterans in West Virginia with 7 counts of second-degree murder. She is accused of killing patients by injecting them with insulin.
https://t.co/iJNtWOuGLM

name: NPR
text:
Robotics wiz and electrical engineer Grant Imahara died on Monday at the age of 49. He was best known as a member of the "Build Team" on the Discovery show "Mythbusters."
https://t.co/HH64x3aJEa

name: NPR
text:
The Justice Department put Daniel Lee to death today â€” marking the first federal execution since 2003.

Lee's lawyer says he was strapped to a gurney for 4 hours as legal obstacles were cleared, and that he was executed without her being notified first. https://t.co/08gqEfEveB

name: NPR
text:
On Sunday, Florida reported 15,300 new coronavirus cases â€” the most so far from any state.

"Miami is now the epicenter of the pandemic," an infectious disease expert says. "What we were seeing in Wuhan â€¦ 5 months ago, now we are there."
https://t.co/tEXncpIfKD

name: NPR
text: Joe Biden outlined an $2 trillion climate plan to boost clean energy, which includes achieving a carbon pollution-free power sector by 2035 and upgrading millions of buildings to increase energy efficiency. https://t.co/IB0ivOgi92

name: NPR
text: Nearly 100 years later, officials are digging for the mass graves from the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre, in which as many as 300 African American residents were slaughtered by white mobs. https://t.co/sEAtGEfszM
